subtitles.text: Fai schifo cucinare, ja totalmente schifo!
Today we're not making spaghetti carbonara.
Some might say it looks like carbonara, and tastes like carbonara, and has the mouthfeel of carbonara, the substances which make up carbonara, and even the personality of carbonara.
But this is not carbonara.
The first thing we're gonna do is chop up some bacon.
That's how you know this isn't carbonara, because if you were making carbonara, you'd be using guanciale.
You see, bacon comes from a pig, whereas guanciale comes from a completely different animal, known as an Italian hog.
Oh my god, it looks like a jumping Italian horse!
You wouldn't make a hamburger with tiger meat, would you?
I really hope not.
Tigers are expensive.
Carbonara is typically made with egg yolks, which is irrelevant, since that's not what we're making.
Don't accidentally use egg yolkles, because banjo music really ruins this dish.
We'll just do the classic hold the yolk with your thumb trick.
You can also do the back and forth, and whoops, maybe no forth.
Then make the traditional Italian egg white on toast as an appetizer.
Mmm.
This is pecorino romano, which you would use if you're making carbonara, which we are not.
It gets its name because the Romans who made it had huge pecs.
So did the goats.
They worked out together.
If you want to shred your pecorino more easily, you can take a drill, put in a nice big fat screw, then you just... okay.
So, whoop.
All right.
If I just maybe... okay, let's try.
Nope.
Hmm.
See, in my mind when I thought of this, none of the physics of how objects work would be an issue.
If you're Italian, you don't need to innovate in this department, because you simply harness the power of your hand gesture muscles, which makes this a breeze.
So grate that into the egg yolk and wang jangle until you've got Cadbury cream egg filling.
Then we'll add some pepper pepper pepper, and we're good to go.
And by go, I mean stay, because we're not done yet.
The original carbonara was made with handcrafted artisan spaghetti from the Veneto region.
Each spaghetti craftsperson had their signature style.
Sadly, these days you can only find straight parallel line spaghetti.
And you know, it just really angers me that the craft has been left to die like nobody cares.
Now, let's just fix that.
Breaking spaghetti in half is a crime in Italy and can land you in prison for up to nine months.
It sounds like an overreaction at first, but the crack sends a shock wave through the noodle, rendering it completely inedible.
I mean, look, here's uncracked spaghetti and cracked spaghetti.
If I didn't tell you that was spaghetti, you wouldn't have even recognized it.
Now we'll salt this angry water, then throw in 156 pieces of spaghetti.
Keep wang jangling that for the first bit to keep the spag from getting clingy.
By the way, spaghetti gets its name because you put it in the spa to cook it.
Now our bacon is cooked.
We're turning the burner off, waiting for this to cool, at least until there's no sizzle left, and a bit longer so we don't overcook the eggbased sauce.
Now I'm gonna put in a bit of pasta water into our sauce ingredients to get that cheeseahead start on the melting.
Noodles go straight from the water into the bacon pan for a wang jangulation.

Since noodles are made of wheat, this is essentially a bacon sandwich, but if you do strain the spaghetti, make sure to set aside some pasta water, and if you get the kind of spaghetti with dehydrated meatballs, just pull those out and set them aside.

Then the sauce can go in, and the egg will cook just enough from the noodle heat, although you can put your pan on low to thicken it as well, because here comes more pasta water, making this nice and creamy.
The reason we add pasta water is so that if you get thirsty while you eat it, you don't have to stop and have a drink.
Here I'm trying to do that fancy twist thing, but it's not the right tool, and I don't know what I'm doing.
We'll finish with some pepper pepper pepper, and some more pecorino or parmesan, and here we don't have carbonara.

If you want to really see not carbonara, here's an earlier attempt where I used whole egg, too much heat, and for some reason this came out way worse than my first attempt with whole egg, which came out great.
So are the whims of the food gods.
If this was carbonara, you'd have to be careful, because the carbonistic properties are so fragile, that if you put in a single pea, it would no longer be carbonara.
It's a mysterious chemical reaction that only Italian scientists understand.
I'm craving carbonara, but I don't have guanciale.
Should I really even bother?
Oh no, will they judge my carbonara?
Because I want some cream upon it.
Should I eat it in the closet?
Oh no, what have I done?
I've added peas to a dish that is otherwise vegetablefree.
They say it's no game.
Hang my head as I eat this not carbonara in shame.

steps: Chop bacon into small pieces.
Cook the bacon in a pan until crispy, then turn off the heat and let it cool slightly.
Separate egg yolks from egg whites and place the yolks in a bowl.
Grate pecorino romano cheese and add it to the egg yolks.
Add freshly ground black pepper to the egg yolk and cheese mixture.
Boil water in a pot, add salt, and cook spaghetti until al dente.
Reserve some pasta water before draining the spaghetti.
Add a small amount of pasta water to the egg yolk and cheese mixture to help melt the cheese.
Transfer the cooked spaghetti directly from the pot to the pan with bacon.
Mix the spaghetti with the bacon and then add the egg yolk mixture, stirring quickly to create a creamy sauce.
Add more pasta water if needed to achieve the desired sauce consistency.
Finish with additional grated pecorino romano and black pepper before serving.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Ingredients-1
materials: Egg yolks - separated from egg whites
outcomes: Bacon is chopped into small pieces
Cheese is grated
Egg mixture is prepared with grated cheese and pepper
tools: Bowl - for mixing egg yolks and cheese
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Chop the bacon into small pieces. Grate the Pecorino Romano cheese. Separate the egg yolks from the whites and mix the yolks with the grated cheese and pepper.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The bacon is used instead of guanciale, which is traditional for carbonara, but this is not a traditional carbonara recipe. The egg yolks are mixed with cheese to create a creamy sauce base.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use the classic 'hold the yolk with your thumb' trick to separate the egg yolks easily. Grate the cheese into the egg yolk and mix until it resembles Cadbury cream egg filling.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Don't accidentally use egg whites in the mixture, as it will not create the desired creamy texture.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Spaghetti-2
materials: Spaghetti: Long, thin cylindrical pasta used as the main ingredient.
Salt: White crystalline substance used to season the water.
outcomes: Spaghetti cooked until al dente: The pasta is firm to the bite, not too soft or overcooked.
tools: Pot: A large container used to boil water and cook the spaghetti.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Boil water in a pot, add salt to the boiling water, and then add 156 pieces of spaghetti. Stir the spaghetti initially to prevent it from sticking together. Cook the spaghetti until it is al dente.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The reason for adding salt to the water is to season the pasta as it cooks. Stirring the spaghetti initially helps prevent it from sticking together.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Keep stirring the spaghetti for the first bit to prevent it from getting clingy.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Breaking spaghetti in half is considered a culinary crime in Italy and can ruin the texture of the pasta.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Ingredients-1
outcomes: Bacon is chopped into small pieces
Cheese is grated
Egg mixture is prepared with grated cheese and pepper
tools: Bowl - for mixing egg yolks and cheese
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Chop the bacon into small pieces. Grate the Pecorino Romano cheese. Separate the egg yolks from the whites and mix the yolks with the grated cheese and pepper.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The cheese is grated to mix with the egg yolks, creating a creamy sauce base. The bacon is chopped to be cooked and mixed with the pasta later.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use the classic hold the yolk with your thumb trick to separate the egg yolks easily. Grate the cheese finely to ensure it mixes well with the egg yolks.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Don't accidentally use egg whites in the mixture, as it will affect the texture of the sauce.

subgoal_summaries.title: Combine Ingredients-4
outcomes: creamy sauce
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Combine the cooked spaghetti directly from the water into the bacon pan. Add the sauce mixture, and let the heat from the noodles cook the egg just enough. Optionally, put the pan on low heat to thicken the sauce. Add more pasta water to achieve a creamy consistency. Finish with pepper and cheese.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The heat from the noodles will cook the egg in the sauce just enough, and adding pasta water helps achieve a creamy consistency.
subgoal_summaries.tips: If you strain the spaghetti, set aside some pasta water to use in the sauce.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Ensure the bacon pan is not too hot to avoid overcooking the egg-based sauce.

subgoal_summaries.title: Reserve Pasta Water-5
outcomes: Reserved pasta water for use in the sauce
tools: A container to hold the reserved pasta water
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Before draining the spaghetti, set aside some of the pasta water to use in the sauce.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The pasta water is used to help melt the cheese and create a creamy sauce when combined with the other ingredients.
subgoal_summaries.tips: If you strain the spaghetti, make sure to set aside some pasta water.

subgoal_summaries.title: Combine Ingredients-4
materials: pecorino or parmesan cheese (visual: finely grated cheese)
outcomes: creamy sauce (visual: smooth, glossy coating on spaghetti)
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Combine the cooked spaghetti with the bacon in the pan. Add the egg mixture to the pan and stir to coat the spaghetti. Add pasta water as needed to achieve a creamy consistency. Finish with pepper and cheese.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The egg will cook from the heat of the noodles, creating a creamy sauce. Adding pasta water helps to achieve the desired consistency and ensures the sauce is smooth.
subgoal_summaries.tips: You can put the pan on low heat to thicken the sauce if needed. Make sure to add pasta water gradually to control the sauce's consistency.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Ensure the bacon pan is not too hot when adding the egg mixture to prevent scrambling the eggs.

subgoal_summaries.title: Adjust Sauce-7
materials: Reserved pasta water (visual: a small bowl of cloudy water)
outcomes: The sauce reaches a creamy consistency (visual: sauce coating the pasta smoothly)
tools: Pan (visual: a frying pan with bacon and pasta)
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Add some reserved pasta water to the sauce ingredients to help melt the cheese. Then, after adding the noodles to the bacon pan, add more pasta water to the sauce to achieve a creamy consistency.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The pasta water helps melt the cheese and achieve a creamy sauce consistency. It also allows the egg to cook just enough from the heat of the noodles without overcooking.
subgoal_summaries.tips: If you strain the spaghetti, make sure to set aside some pasta water for adjusting the sauce consistency.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Be careful not to overcook the egg-based sauce by ensuring the pan is not too hot when adding the sauce ingredients.

subgoal_summaries.title: Finish and Serve-8
materials: Pecorino or Parmesan cheese, finely grated
outcomes: The dish is finished with a garnish of additional cheese and black pepper, enhancing its flavor and presentation.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Finish the dish by adding some freshly ground black pepper and a generous amount of finely grated Pecorino or Parmesan cheese on top before serving.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: Adding extra cheese and black pepper at the end enhances the flavor and gives the dish a classic carbonara finish.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use freshly grated cheese and freshly ground black pepper for the best flavor.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Be careful not to add too much cheese or pepper, as it can overpower the dish.

steps: Cut about half a pound of thick-cut bacon into three-quarter inch pieces.
Heat a pan over medium heat and add a tiny bit of olive oil (optional).
Add the bacon to the pan and slowly render out the fat until the bacon is crispy.
Boil about four quarts of water and add a tablespoon of kosher salt.
Grate three ounces each of Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheese.
In a bowl, whisk together three whole eggs and two egg yolks.
Mix the grated cheeses into the egg mixture.
Add fresh ground black pepper to the egg and cheese mixture to taste.
Once the bacon is crispy, remove some for garnish and drain most of the fat, leaving about two tablespoons in the pan. Turn off the heat.
Cook spaghetti in the boiling water until slightly al dente, about 10 minutes.
Transfer the cooked spaghetti to the pan with the bacon using tongs, leaving the pasta water in the pot.
Add the egg and cheese mixture to the hot spaghetti, stirring gently to coat the pasta without scrambling the eggs.
If the sauce is too thick, add a little reserved pasta water to loosen it.
Plate the pasta and garnish with more grated Parmigiano Reggiano and crispy bacon.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Ingredients-1
outcomes: Bacon chopped into small pieces
Cheese grated finely
Egg mixture prepared with cheese and pepper
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Chop the bacon into small pieces, about three-quarters of an inch thick. Grate about three ounces each of Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheese using a cheese grater or the fine setting on a box grater. Crack three whole eggs and two egg yolks into a bowl, whisk them together, and then whisk in the grated cheese. Add fresh ground black pepper to taste and whisk it into the egg mixture.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The mixture of both Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheeses is used for a balanced flavor. The combination of whole eggs and egg yolks provides richness without being overly heavy. Fresh ground black pepper is added for seasoning and flavor.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use a mixture of Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano for a balanced flavor. Adjust the amount of black pepper to your preference.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Be careful not to scramble the eggs when mixing them with the cheese and pepper.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Spaghetti-2
materials: Spaghetti: Long, thin pasta used as the base of the dish.
Kosher salt: Coarse salt used to season the pasta water.
outcomes: Spaghetti cooked to al dente: The pasta is firm to the bite, not too soft or overcooked.
tools: Pot: Used to boil water and cook the spaghetti.
Tongs: Used to handle and transfer the spaghetti.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Fill a pot with about four quarts of water and bring it to a boil. Add about a tablespoon of kosher salt to the boiling water. Add the spaghetti to the pot and cook it for about 10 minutes until it is slightly al dente. Use tongs to remove the spaghetti from the pot.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The pasta water is seasoned with less salt than usual because carbonara contains many salty elements. Cooking the spaghetti to al dente ensures it will not become too soft when mixed with the sauce later.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use cheap Italian pasta brands for better texture and taste. Leave the pasta water in the pot after removing the spaghetti, as it can be used later to adjust the sauce consistency.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Be careful not to overcook the spaghetti, as it will continue to cook slightly when mixed with the sauce.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Ingredients-1
outcomes: Bacon chopped into small pieces
Cheese grated finely
Egg mixture prepared with cheese and pepper
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Chop the bacon into small pieces, about three-quarters of an inch thick. Grate about three ounces each of Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheese using a cheese grater or the fine setting on a box grater. For the egg mixture, use three whole eggs and two egg yolks, whisk them together, and then whisk in the grated cheese. Add fresh ground black pepper to taste and whisk it in. Optionally, add a little boiling water to the egg mixture to loosen it up.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The mixture of both Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheeses is used for a balanced flavor. The egg mixture is a combination of whole eggs and yolks to maintain richness without being overly heavy. Adding boiling water to the egg mixture helps equalize temperatures and makes the pasta come together more easily.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use a mixture of Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano for a balanced flavor. Add boiling water to the egg mixture to help it come together more easily.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Be careful not to scramble the eggs when mixing them with the pasta later.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Spaghetti-2
materials: Spaghetti: Long, thin pasta used as the base of the dish.
Kosher salt: Coarse salt used to season the pasta water.
outcomes: Spaghetti cooked to al dente: The pasta is firm to the bite, not too soft or overcooked.
tools: Pot: Used to boil water and cook the spaghetti.
Tongs: Used to handle and transfer the spaghetti.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Bring a pot of water to a boil. Add about a tablespoon of kosher salt to the water. Once the water is boiling, add the spaghetti. Cook the spaghetti for about 10 minutes until it is slightly al dente.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The pasta water is seasoned with less salt than usual because carbonara contains many salty elements. Cooking the spaghetti to al dente ensures it will not become too soft when finished in the pan with the sauce.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use tongs to handle the spaghetti easily. Leave the pasta water in the pot after removing the spaghetti, as it can be used later to adjust the sauce consistency.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Be careful not to overcook the spaghetti, as it will continue to cook slightly when mixed with the sauce.

subgoal_summaries.title: Combine Ingredients-5
materials: egg and cheese mixture (made from Pecorino Romano, Parmigiano Reggiano, eggs, and egg yolks)
outcomes: A creamy sauce that coats the spaghetti without scrambling the eggs.
A velvety, fluffy, and creamy pasta dish.
tools: pan (used for mixing spaghetti with the sauce)
La Crusade pan (or similar, which holds heat well)
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Use tongs to transfer the cooked spaghetti into the pan with the reserved bacon fat. Add the egg and cheese mixture to the hot spaghetti. Gently mix to coat the spaghetti, ensuring the eggs cook from the heat of the pasta without scrambling. If the sauce is too thick, add a little reserved pasta water to loosen it and create a creamy sauce.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The heat from the spaghetti will cook the eggs gently, creating a creamy sauce without scrambling them. The reserved pasta water can be used to adjust the sauce's consistency, ensuring it remains creamy without adding cream.
subgoal_summaries.tips: If the sauce doesn't thicken as desired, place the pan over simmering pasta water to gently heat it further, acting like a double boiler. This is especially useful if the pan doesn't retain heat well.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Be careful not to scramble the eggs by ensuring the heat is off and mixing gently. Avoid breaking the spaghetti while mixing.

subgoal_summaries.title: Adjust Sauce-6
materials: Reserved pasta water (visual: clear liquid in a pot)
outcomes: The sauce achieves a creamy consistency without using cream (visual: smooth, glossy sauce coating the pasta)
subgoal_summaries.instructions: If the sauce looks too thick, add a little bit of the reserved pasta water to loosen it up and help establish a creamy sauce.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: Adding reserved pasta water helps to loosen the sauce and create a creamy consistency without using cream.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use the reserved pasta water to adjust the sauce consistency to your liking.

subgoal_summaries.title: Finish and Serve-7
outcomes: The pasta is finished with additional cheese and black pepper, enhancing its flavor and presentation.
The dish is garnished with crispy bacon, adding texture and a savory element.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Plate the pasta using tongs, then finish by sprinkling more Parmigiano Reggiano cheese and freshly ground black pepper over the top. Add crispy bacon pieces for garnish.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: Adding more cheese and black pepper enhances the flavor and presentation of the dish. The crispy bacon provides an added crunch that complements the creamy pasta.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the cheese is finely grated for even distribution and better melting over the pasta.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Be gentle when plating the pasta to avoid breaking it.

metadata.title: Pasta Carbonara the American Way (With Bacon)

subgoal_definitions.title: Prepare Ingredients
subgoal_definitions.description: Chop bacon into small pieces, grate cheese, and prepare the egg mixture.
original_steps: Cut about half a pound of thick-cut bacon into three-quarter inch pieces.
Heat a pan over medium heat and add a tiny bit of olive oil (optional).
Add the bacon to the pan and slowly render out the fat until the bacon is crispy.
Once the bacon is crispy, remove some for garnish and drain most of the fat, leaving about two tablespoons in the pan. Turn off the heat.
Chop bacon into small pieces.
Cook the bacon in a pan until crispy, then turn off the heat and let it cool slightly.
Grate three ounces each of Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheese.
In a bowl, whisk together three whole eggs and two egg yolks.
Mix the grated cheeses into the egg mixture.
Add fresh ground black pepper to the egg and cheese mixture to taste.
Separate egg yolks from egg whites and place the yolks in a bowl.
Grate pecorino romano cheese and add it to the egg yolks.
Add freshly ground black pepper to the egg yolk and cheese mixture.

subgoal_definitions.title: Cook Bacon
subgoal_definitions.description: Cook the chopped bacon until it is crispy.

subgoal_definitions.title: Cook Spaghetti
subgoal_definitions.description: Boil water, add salt, and cook the spaghetti until it is al dente.
original_steps: Boil about four quarts of water and add a tablespoon of kosher salt.
Cook spaghetti in the boiling water until slightly al dente, about 10 minutes.
Boil water in a pot, add salt, and cook spaghetti until al dente.

subgoal_definitions.title: Reserve Pasta Water
subgoal_definitions.description: Reserve some of the pasta water before draining the spaghetti.
original_steps: Reserve some pasta water before draining the spaghetti.

subgoal_definitions.title: Combine Ingredients
subgoal_definitions.description: Combine the cooked spaghetti with the bacon and egg mixture to create a creamy sauce.
original_steps: Transfer the cooked spaghetti to the pan with the bacon using tongs, leaving the pasta water in the pot.
Add the egg and cheese mixture to the hot spaghetti, stirring gently to coat the pasta without scrambling the eggs.
